utterances: That's inmate Brandon Snider, one of about 80 people serving short sentences here.
Virginia no longer requires ex-cons to check the box identifying themselves as former inmates on state job applications.
Greg Warden, the jail's program's director, says pass the GED test and to a legitimate career path may swing open.
As far as them coming in and learning, these guys come in right off the bat.
They want this so bad.
Frank Fassl dropped out of school in 10th grade and has been in and out of jail ever since.
At first, he thought studying for the GED would be a waste of time.
But his teacher from a local community college inspired him, and he passed on the first try.
Where before I felt because I was a felon, I wasn't never going to have a career or job or anything that mattered.
But now that I got the diploma, I've done the research on what jobs I can have.
While he waits to be released, he mentors other inmates and ponders the future after jail.
I got a cap and gown, which I never had.
I got a tassel, which I never thought I would have.
And I got options now to go to college.
Some county jails stopped offering GED exams because of last year's changes to the equivalency test.
They cite more cumbersome rules for on-site testing centers and not enough teacher training.
Some, like this facility in Virginia, kept their testing programs going despite those challenges.
Here's Cpt.
Kimberly Haug.
One of the reasons why I said whatever it takes to continue this to continue it.

You know, you're talking about 40, 50-year-old men crying, you know, breaking down in tears, saying, you know, I've never accomplished anything in my life until this or - we had to reevaluate and rethink it - you know, what we were doing when we had to decide whether we were going to buy all the computers if we were going to go forward with it.
We knew we wanted to.
The following drama contains adult content.
Viewer discretion is advised.
She was built in 1998, out in Seattle.
Cruise it about 1,000 miles without refueling.
I tow a 38-foot tender to go fishing with, and I take two jet skis and an inflatable tender on deck.
Stepping into the main saloon, it's comfortable - polished wood furnishings and elegant decor you'd expect from a boat with a multimillion-dollar price tag.
There are entertainment systems.
There are couches.
It's all covered with (unintelligible) that go outside.
I mean, we have granite countertops here, and looks like a very nice entertainment center.
Right.
We got a nice dining table.
Got a full bar with an icemaker.
At 108 feet, the Must Be Dreaming looks huge when docked elsewhere.
But here at Fort Lauderdale Sunrise Harbor Marina, it has lots of company, and many of the other boats are larger.
Yachts this size used to be rare.
Nowadays, yachts 200 feet, 300 feet, even 400 feet long are not unusual.
They can command prices over $50 million.
And even at that price, there's a shortage of boats just like there are shortage of places to keep them.
Dave Culver is the marina manager at Sunrise Harbor.
We were built specifically to cater to the larger scale of the yachts.
But again, there's just so many of them being built, and there's just nowhere in South Florida to really put them all.
They have to call months ahead to even get a spot here.
(Soundbite of seagulls singing)
That's the kind of mega-yacht Marina Miami wants to build here on Watson Island.
Today, the island in the shadow of Biscayne Bay is home to a few marinas, a children's museum and Parrot Jungle Island, a tourist attraction.
But Mehmet Bayraktar thinks Watson Island can be much more.
There is no other location to compare in South Florida.
Bayraktar is a developer, originally from Turkey, with plans to build a $480 million complex on Watson Island.
The centerpiece would be a 50-slip, mega-yacht marina, capable of handling boats up to 465 feet long.
The development would also include two high-rise hotel towers, shopping and restaurant space, a museum and a park.
Bayraktar says when it's complete, Miami will rival Monaco, St. Tropez and St. Barts as a mega-yacht destination.
It's a place for everyone.
You can be basically, coming there for a cup of coffee.
You can have your $50 million yacht brought there for a week or three months of the year, or you can be sleeping any of the hotels.
There's little question now that the project will be built.
It was approved five years ago in a voter referendum.
It has the approval of federal, state and local officials.
But there are a few lone voices in Miami asking whether building a playground for the wealthy is really the best way to use public land.
Nancy Liebman is president of the Urban Environment League of Greater Miami.
Watson Island is one of the most gorgeous pieces of property with a 360-degree water view.
No wonder there's a developer trying to grab up the land.
The Miami-Dade County Commission still has to approve a dredging permit for the marina.
County Commissioner Carlos Gimenez was Miami's city manager when he helped sell the idea to the public five years ago.
So what we wanted to do with Watson Island was to create a destination, and also leave some open spaces so that people would come to the island and enjoy the waterfront.
And then Watson Island will become alive, you know, where in the past, it was basically just a dead island.
Gimenez says there are just a few details that need to be resolved before the project can go forward.
Nancy Liebman says at this point, the most her group can hope for are some guarantees that the Watson Island Development will truly welcome everyone, not just millionaire owners of mega-yachts.
Greg Allen, NPR News, Miami.
From NPR News, this is All Things Considered.
I'm Michele Norris.
And I'm Robert Siegel.
More scorching reviews today for the government's controversial $700 billion financial-rescue program.
The congressionally appointed panel overseeing the program issued its first report today.
And the report posed 10 questions that the panel will try to answer over the next six months.
They include: Is the strategy helping to reduce foreclosures, and is the public receiving a fair deal?
During a hearing to accept the report, lawmakers suggested that they were not encouraged by what they'd learned so far.
NPR's John Ydstie reports.
The congressional oversight panel had its first meeting just two weeks ago.
It's headed by Harvard professor Elizabeth Warren.
She told lawmakers the questions the panel will try to answer are its best efforts to capture the concerns of real Americans.
I'll just tell you the highlights.
We have 10 questions.
What is Treasury's overall strategy?
Is the strategy working?
How are taxpayer dollars being used?
Not very well, was the view of lawmakers even before they heard from Professor Warren.
She'd been preceded at the witness table by Neel Kashkari, who runs the $700 billion TARP program at the Treasury.
And he probably wishes he'd called in sick this morning.

It started with a relatively calm admonition from committee Chairman Barney Frank of Massachusetts that the Treasury's failure to use TARP funds to help struggling homeowners might keep Congress from releasing the second half of the $700 billion program.

Lawmakers, including Democrat David Scott of Georgia, repeatedly asked Kashkari whether the Treasury is monitoring the use of the hundreds of billions of dollars in capital the Treasury has injected into banks.
The infusion is supposed to induce banks to increase lending and boost the economy.
Scott said it's not happening.
The banks won't lend it.
Here we have sent them $290 billion, but they won't lend it.
Kashkari responded that it's too early to know if the program is working.
He did say Treasury is working with bank regulators to try to determine if lending is increasing.
Treasury's rescue of insurance giant AIG also came under fire, specifically for multimillion-dollar bonuses paid to some AIG executives.
Here's California Democrat Brad Sherman questioning Kashkari.
So there'd be a little crunch.
Well, it depends on what form it takes, but you know, the one thing that unifies Republicans typically, from Maine to Mississippi, is tax relief.

And depending upon how this tax component is crafted, it could well have broad Republican appeal and make it much more likely that the measure passes with broad bipartisan support, which is what the new president would like and what we would like.
If you are not satisfied with the shape or size of this package, is there any possibility you would resort to a filibuster?
Well, if you mean, will something in the Senate require 60 votes?
(Laughing) That's true of almost everything these days.
I don't think that this measure's going to have any problem getting over 60 votes.
And in fact, President-elect Obama has said he's targeting even a much higher number of Republicans.
Yeah, he would like to have the bill supported on a broad bipartisan basis.
So, you know, we all understand the need to do something and to do it quickly, and I think how it's ultimately crafted will determine how many Republicans support it.
Could we go back for a moment to talk of the deficit?
Which is a record deficit, $1.2 trillion, for this budget year.
What steps would you support in the long run to lower the national debt?
I'm asking, would you consider Social Security cuts, cuts in Medicare?
The two huge systemic spending problems we have long-term everybody is aware of; Medicare and Social Security are simply unsustainable.
I expect the current economic crisis will actually show down our willingness and ability to tackle those issues, but they're there.
Well, it certainly makes it less appetizing, let's say, if there are more people unemployed, to talk about cutting Medicare or cutting...
Yeah, well, I, you know...
Social Security.
Exactly what's going to be done is another matter.
We can't negotiate what can be done here this morning on this program.
But what we do know is they're not sustainable at the current levels.
It cannot be left alone in perpetuity.
